normalised: **Manufacturing and Supply Chain: Accurate Inventory Forecasting Key to Navigating Festive Season Demand Surge**

unnormalised: Mumbai, India – 20/10/2024 – Indian manufacturers are ramping up efforts to refine their inventory forecasting models ahead of Diwali, a period known for its exponential demand surge. A recent report from IIM Bangalore highlighted that inaccurate forecasting cost the Indian manufacturing sector an estimated Rs. 500 crore last year alone.
normalised: Mumbai, India – twentieth October two thousand and twenty four – Indian manufacturers are ramping up efforts to refine their inventory forecasting models ahead of Diwali, a period known for its exponential demand surge. A recent report from I I M Bangalore highlighted that inaccurate forecasting cost the Indian manufacturing sector an estimated rupee five hundred crore last year alone.

unnormalised: Companies like Tata Steel and Mahindra & Mahindra are investing heavily in AI-powered solutions to predict demand fluctuations with greater precision. The models incorporate diverse datasets, including historical sales data, weather patterns, and even social media sentiment analysis related to upcoming festivals and auspicious dates. “Our target is to reduce stockouts by at least 15% by December 2024,” stated Ms. Priya Sharma, Supply Chain Head at Godrej Consumer Products.

unnormalised: Challenges remain, particularly in predicting demand for regional specialties and handcrafted items. Several SMEs are participating in workshops on 25/10/2024 at 10:00 hrs, organized by the Ministry of MSME, focusing on leveraging data analytics for better inventory management. Initial results from pilots indicate a potential reduction in wastage by up to 8% by Q1 2025 for firms adopting these techniques.
